abstract.text: A notification that an app can schedule for presentation at a specific date and time.

inlineContent.text: Use
instead.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The operating system is responsible for delivering local notifications at their scheduled times; the app does not have to be running for this to happen. Although local notifications are similar to remote notifications in that they are used for displaying alerts, playing sounds, and badging app icons, they are composed and delivered locally and do not require connection with remote servers.

Local notifications are primarily intended for apps with timer-based behaviors and simple calendar or to-do list apps. An app that is running in the background may also schedule a local notification to inform the user of an incoming message, chat, or update. An app can have only a limited number of scheduled notifications; the system keeps the soonest-firing 64 notifications (with automatically rescheduled notifications counting as a single notification) and discards the rest.

When you create a local notification, you must specify either a specific date or a geographic region as the trigger for delivering the notification. Date-based notifications are delivered at the day and time you specify, and allowances can be made for time zone changes as needed. Region-based notifications are delivered when the user enters or exits the specified region. In both cases, you can specify whether the notifications are one-time events or can be rescheduled and delivered again.
After creating a
object, schedule it using either the
or
method of the
class. The
method uses the fire date to schedule delivery; the
method presents the notification immediately, regardless of the value of
. You can cancel one or more local notifications using the
or
method of the
object.

When the system delivers a local notification, several things can happen, depending on the app state and the type of notification. If the app is not frontmost and visible, the system displays the alert message, badges the app, and plays a sound—whatever is specified in the notification. If the notification is an alert and the user taps the action button (or, if the device is locked, drags open the action slider), the app is woken up or launched. (If the user taps one of the custom actions you specify using the
property, the app is woken up or launched into the background.) In its
method, the app delegate can obtain the
object from the launch options dictionary using the
key. The delegate can inspect the properties of the notification and, if the notification includes custom data in its
dictionary, it can access that data and process it accordingly. On the other hand, if the local notification only badges the app icon, and the user in response launches the app, the
method is called, but no
object is included in the options dictionary. When the user selects a custom action, the app delegate’s
method is called to handle the action.
If the app is foremost and visible when the system delivers the notification, the app delegate’s
is called to process the notification. Use the information in the provided
object to decide what action to take. The system does not display any alerts, badge the app’s icon, or play any sounds when the app is already frontmost.

An app is responsible for managing the badge number displayed on its icon. For example, if a text-messaging app processes all incoming messages after receiving a local notification, it should remove the icon badge by setting the
property of the
object to 0.

abstract.text: A request to schedule a local notification, which includes the content of the notification and the trigger conditions for delivery.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An acceleration event that represents immediate, three-dimensional acceleration data.
An object that lets you register to receive acceleration-related data from the onboard hardware.
A view that presents a set of alternatives for how to proceed with a task.
A view that displays an alert message.
The centralized point of control and coordination for apps running in iOS.
A key indicating that the app was launched to handle a local notification.
The number currently set as the badge of the app icon on the Home screen.
Cancels the delivery of all scheduled local notifications.
Cancels the delivery of the specified scheduled local notification.
Presents a local notification immediately.
Schedules a local notification for delivery at its encapsulated date and time.
Tells the delegate that the launch process is almost done and the app is almost ready to run.
Sent to the delegate when a running app receives a local notification.
Called when your app has been activated because user selected a custom action from the alert panel of a local notification.
A list of all the available document providers for a given file type and mode, in addition to custom menu items that you add.
A notification that an app can schedule for presentation at a specific date and time.
The title of the action button or slider.
The message displayed in the notification alert.
Identifies the image used as the launch image when the user taps (or slides) the action button (or slider).
A short description of the reason for the alert.
The number to display as the app’s icon badge.
The name of a group of actions to display in the alert.
The date and time when the system should deliver the notification.
A Boolean value that controls whether the notification shows or hides the alert action.
The geographic region that triggers the notification.
A Boolean value indicating whether crossing a geographic region boundary delivers only one notification.
The calendar the system should refer to when it reschedules a repeating notification.
The calendar interval at which to reschedule the notification.
The name of the file containing the sound to play when an alert is displayed.
The time zone of the notification’s fire date.
A dictionary for passing custom information to the notified app.
The menu interface for the Cut, Copy, Paste, Select, Select All, and Delete commands.
A custom item in the editing menu managed by the menu controller.
A modifiable version of the user notification action class.
Information about custom actions that your app can perform in response to a local or push notification.
An object that manages the presentation of content in a popover.
A preview action, or

inlineContent.text: peek quick action

abstract.text: , that displays below a peek when a user swipes the peek upward.
A group of one or more child quick actions, each an instance of the preview action class.
An object that manages the display of a search bar, along with a table view that displays search results.
A specific type of segue for presenting content in a popover.
A custom action that your app can perform in response to a remote or local notification.
Information about custom actions that your app can perform in response to a local or push notification.
The types of notifications that can be displayed to the user by your app.
The default system sound for local notifications.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.

A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
